Hi Tan.  There are a few broad issues with this commit:

1. We don't accept new patches in meta-layers and we have been slowly getting rid of any of the legacy ones.
2. `meta-arm` is something we import directly from upstream open-embedded layers and shouldn't be modified.

What is "FVP"?  Is this some kind of evaluation board that ARM puts out?  If so, we could move some this to meta-evb.  If not, who manufacturers this board?

I would also suggest breaking this commit into multiple.  There is a lot here.  Get a basic commit that adds the machine and compiles and then add commits on top of it for various functions.

I'm one of the co-maintainers of the meta-arm layer, so can offer some insight.

A FVP is an Arm Fixed Virtual Platform, basically a software simulation of a complete Arm system.  Think of it as an incredibly accurate proprietary qemu-like for Arm systems and you're close.

meta-arm has a MACHINE called 'fvp-base' which targets the base Armv8-A platform. Specifically, the Armv8-A Base Architecture Envelope Model Fixed Virtual Platform as mentioned in the commit.

This commit appears to copy-and-paste the fvp-base machine into a new sublayer meta-fvp in meta-arm that is specific to OpenBMC.  Obviously this is now very confusing: meta-arm would have one machine called fvp and another called fvp-base, and a meta-fvp layer that isn't actually a generic fvp layer despite the name.

As a meta-arm maintainer I'm not convinced that we should be hosting project-specific BSPs in meta-arm itself, instead openbmc could have a small layer that contains a new machine using meta-arm and inheriting fvp-base.

Thank you Ross for context.  Agree.  

We usually have either `meta-<mfg>` or `meta-<mfg>-openbmc` for machines by those vendors and we also have `meta-evb` for evaluation boards.  This kind of sounds similar to an EVB to me, just one in a software and/or hardware emulator.

Tan should be able to work with you to determine how much of the existing `meta-arm/fvp` he can build on and then contribute anything that explicitly depends on our `meta-phosphor` layer as a separate machine-layer here.

To reiterate what Patrick said here, I suspect in this case we need the openbmc-specific stuff to move to a folder called meta-arm-openbmc.  This is the same thing we had to do for meta-intel, to differentiate meta-intel (the generic host support) and meta-intel-openbmc (openbmc-specific patches produced by Intel).  This situation seems identical, and we can follow the same playbook.

The generic portions should be submitted to meta-arm upstream, which we can then sync back down to openbmc/openbmc/meta-arm (which happens via scripting).

pretty sure we want this marked as an open issue and not resolved.

Agree with everything Patrick said.
Partial review.

Hi all, thank you all for your kind review and feedback into this patch - much appreciated. sorry for late reply, just got back from vacation, absorbing all the feedbacks now and planning the new patch :)
Thank you Ross, Patrick and Ed for the feedback. This is very sensible approach, i will move it to meta-arm-openbmc for now.
That sounds pretty reasonable, thanks for the feedback Patrick and Ed. I have moved to the meta-arm, and will submit the features (PLDM etc) as a follow up patch after this patch.
Hi @Ross, Parick and Ed, thank you for the review and proposal for this. I have moved to meta-evb as per the latest patchset. I presume this should be ok now?
Done
Will mark this as resolved, feel free to reopen it if needed :)
Generally docmentation of this form would go into the docs folder, although I don't think we have machine-specific docs yet, this seems like an opportunity to start.

People will naturally look for documentation where the actual code is.

Keeping the documentation close to the implementation
(or at least in the same repository) increases the chances of someone finding it or fixing it if it becomes outdated eventually.
You've added these here AND in distro features.  Ideally everything would use distro features, but we definitely shouldn't duplicate.
Done

Several of these are already the default for the obmc distro.  Either this machine is:

1. a generic machine, in which case adding openbmc things is inappropriate.
2. an openbmc specific machine, in which case it should be inheriting from the default distro.
Done
These need done in a distro layer, not a machine layer.

Will close this as this is being discussed here:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/70070/comment/4a963c24_75b11840/

and I have also push the fix as another patch here:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/71017

Will proceed to mark this as resolved for now.

I don't think a custom image type is required on other machines, any reason it's required here?
Good point, done removed.
Ideally this would be a PACKAGECONFIG item that you submit to the main trusted-firmware-a recipe, but just removing it is fine.
Done

There is a change to make error logging the default.  Please remove this for now, and if you find that the level of logging you have is insufficient, please let me know, and we can adjust.


Logging=enabled (which is the same as logging debug) prints waaaaaaaaay too much to the console to be a default.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/69576
Thankds Ed. WIll incorporate into next patch.
I believe this is now the default, so this can be removed.
Will include these changes in follow up patch, this patch will be the base patch.
Please don't check in patch files to projects that openbmc maintains.  Start a discussion with the PLDM maintainers, and open a gerrit review to get your changes included.
Sure, removed. Will restructure PLDM into the follow up patch.
Done
Please set to `nanbield scarthgap` to match all the other layer.conf we have.
Done
It seems like something is missing if you're needing to set this here.  We already set this in image_types_phosphor.bbclass.
Done
Why?  This is already done by `obmc-bsp-common.inc` isn't it?
Done
Why?
Done removed.
Something is missing if you've had to do this.
Done removed.
Is this a copy paste from somewhere else?
Done removed.
Why?
Done removed.
Why?

it has this build error if i did not remove it:
ERROR: btrfs-tools-native-6.7.1-r0 do_configure: configure failed
ERROR: btrfs-tools-native-6.7.1-r0 do_configure: ExecutionError('/home/stan/bmc/arm-internal-openbmc-repo/build/fvp-base/tmp/work/x86_64-linux/btrfs-tools-native/6.7.1/temp/run.do_configure.1111247', 1, None, None)
ERROR: Logfile of failure stored in: /home/stan/bmc/arm-internal-openbmc-repo/build/fvp-base/tmp/work/x86_64-linux/btrfs-tools-native/6.7.1/temp/log.do_configure.1111247

Can you get more details on the failure?  Nobody else is doing this in all of openbmc, openembedded and poky.

You'll need to look at the `log.do_configure` file listed there for more specifics on what went wrong during that portion of the build.
Done removed, sorry for the confusion.
Done
Wait it is not removed - will investigate further.

looking for

	meta-phosphor/conf/distro/include/phosphor-base.inc
it requires
	meta-phosphor/conf/distro/include/phosphor-pkg-tweaks.inc

which has following contents to fix the build:

	# Disable python from btrfs-tools
	PACKAGECONFIG:remove:pn-btrfs-tools = "python"

but this does not apply to the '-native' version of the recipe.

Building the native version is probably caused by us setting
	WKS_FILE
variable, which other boards do aswell.

	poky/meta/classes-recipe/image_types_wic.bbclass
	WKS_FILE_DEPENDS_DEFAULT += "bmaptool-native cdrtools-native btrfs-tools-native squashfs-tools-native e2fsprogs-native erofs-utils-native"

WKS_FILE_DEPENDS is set by

	meta-aspeed/conf/machine/include/aspeed.inc
	meta-nuvoton/conf/machine/include/nuvoton.inc
	meta-arm/meta-arm/conf/machine/qemuarm-secureboot.conf
	...

to avoid the default value, and avoid building btrfs-tools-native.

This is my take on why it's not building without that change.
Could be wrong though.

Let's put this in meta-phosphor then if it is something everyone is going to need.  I'm not sure why we need it though.  I still haven't seen the `log.do_configure` that is reporting the problem.  Is this just a missing DEPENDS for the python config?

Sure, i published by do_configure build error here:
https://dpaste.org/awKH5

Please let me know if I need to check anything else.

I have also upstreamed the patch to fix here, please have a look:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/71017

Done the fix here, will mark as resolved:
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/71252
For some history for reference in the future regarding the discussion with OE community, please refer here:
https://lists.openembedded.org/g/openembedded-core/topic/105729019
Why?
Done removed.

I added it back, because without this there will be this error in openbmc shell:
root@fvp:~# [  632.403680] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.
[  664.626080] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.
[  696.850480] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.
[  729.106980] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.
[  761.534680] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.
[  793.854780] systemd-journald[167]: Time jumped backwards, rotating.

It is because FVP could be out of sync with real time due to slower simulation, but I will keep this open as we are discussing with meta-arm developers if they are also seeing this issue.

Ok got the full picture:
the meta-arm is using OpenRC, so it does not has this issue as it does not include time sync daemon.
OpenBMC mandates systemd, and since systemd also includes time sync daemon, and due to the FVP could be simulated at different speed with the real world time hence causing difference in time, thats why this error is printed. So for FVP usecase, we have to disable timesync. I also added the comment in the file.
Will mark as resolved as this is required as explained above. Feel free to reopen if need :)
Please remove meta-poky references.  See e32643cc1d2e68eba52b00758e2d7950223ae273 for where this was already done on the rest of the tree.
Done removed, thanks for the info!
Done
Why are you providing your own fstab file?  This doesn't seem right.
Done removed, managed to get overlay done properly without our own fstab file.
DOne removed.

We do not allow patches.

Isn't this already done in `meta-arm/meta-arm-bsp/recipes-kernel/linux/linux-arm-platforms.inc`?  Why aren't you using it?

Done removed the patch - now the build works. 
meta-arm/meta-arm-bsp/recipes-kernel/linux/linux-arm-platforms.inc is included :)
Will still mark as WIP as still need to evaluate the boot performance.
